Replying to @simonw 2018-05-10 00:53
@simonw @beyond_code @jaggeree Perhaps not quite what you're looking for, but when you build microservices with Lambda via @Netlify Functions, they are atomic, immutable and their versioning and deployment is automatically linked to the rest of your site's versioning. Rollbacks, branch builds... all in sync

The more involved features introduce costs when usage mounts, and other pro features/support-levels cost $

Replying to @ 2018-05-09 14:00
@vincpa @dav_is_dev @ianfeather The conversation from this talk "Building Resilient Frontend Systems" was about what happens if a request for JS made by a document that the browser has *already downloaded* fails. if it was critical for content display, the user is impacted. Put content in HTML. Then enhance.

Replying to @stu_cx 2018-05-05 15:41
@StuCoxMedia @ianfeather BuzzFeed have *millions* of pages, and millions of visitors. Inlining the js would mean that it can't be cached as a common resource and would inflate the weight of every single page request. It would also probably damage the performance too. Progressive Enhancement is the way.
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @gerrybot 2018-05-05 14:35
@gerrybot @nandortoth @GoHugoIO @github @Netlify @awscloud Lambda can be used to extend what you can do with a static site. When you need something to run server-side like a secret you can't have client-side, it can be handy. @Netlify makes it simple for you by letting you manage lambda functions as part of your codebase.
